bird_report.population_additional_info: Population of Moltoni's warbler Sylvia subalpina (Sylvia cantillans moltonii) estimated to be 50000-130000 pairs (Brichetti & Fracasso 2010). The two have been considered together under S. cantillans until a few years ago, and all previous estimates refer to both the two.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Recent trend for S. cantillans/S. subalpina taken together according to common bird monitoring scheme (MITO project) reported to be decline (2000-2010) or increase (2000-2012) (Rete Rurale Nazionale & LIPU 2011. Uccelli comuni in Italia. Gli andamenti di popolazione dal 2000 al 2010, Rete Rurale Nazionale & LIPU 2013. Uccelli comuni in Italia. Gli andamenti di popolazione dal 2000 al 2012). Geographical variation in local trend. Overall, likely to be stable, with recent expansion and increase in northern regions.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Results of national monitoring scheme of common birds suggested decline for 2000-2011 (Rete Rurale Nazionale 2011, Campedelli et al. 2012), and stability (but with negative average variation) for 2000-2013 (Rete Rurale Nazionale & LIPU 2013). Therefore, given the evidence for decline at both regional (Gustin et al. 2010) and national level (Rete Rurale Nazionale 2011, Campedelli et al. 2012) the species is evaluated as decreasing on the long term.

Andamenti di popolazione delle specie comuni in Italia: 2000-2011. Avocetta 36: 121-143, Rete Rurale Nazionale & LIPU 2013). Long-term trend, according to expert opinion, is likely to be stable (Gustin et al. 2010, Brichetti & Fracasso 2011).

Birds in Europe: population estimates, trends and conservation status Cambridge, UK: BirdLife International. BirdLife Conservation Series No. 12). In 1994 estimated 13000-20000 pairs of which 5000-8000 belonging to A. g. graeca, 6000-9000 A. g. saxatilis, 2000-3000 A. g. whitakeri.

Cambridge, UK: BirdLife International. BirdLife Conservation Series No. 3). Rete Rurale Nazionale & LIPU (2013) reported stability (with an overall decline about 5-10% in 2000-2012), but several cases of regional and local declines (Gustin et al. 2009).

The Red-billed Chough Pyrrhocorax pyrrhocorax in Italy 2nd International Workshop on the Conservation of the Chough. 13-14 September 2007. bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Apparent increase from 1980 to 2011 (cfr. Tucker & Heath 1994, Brichetti & Fracasso 2011), but marked decrease reported for some populations (Bernoni M, Brunelli M, De Sanctis E, Sarrocco S & Cecere J, 2009. Status del gracchio corallino, Phyrrocorax phyrrocorax, e del gracchio alpino, Phyrrocorax graculus, nel Lazio (Italia centrale). Riv. Ital. Orn. 78 (2): 99-110; De Sanctis & Laiolo 2007), while other populations are reported to be stable (De Sanctis & Laiolo 2007). Therefore, the overall trend is considered 'unknown'.
